awd_titl_txt: CC* Team: SWEETER -- SouthWest Expertise in Expanding, Training, Education and Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The efficacy of an  interdisciplinary research team is frequently limited by a researcher's ability to draw together a cohort of collaborators with needed scientific expertise.  SWEETER: South West Expertise in Expanding Training, Education and Research is a network of resources, both training and personnel, that collaborate and foster cooperation across the boundaries of disciplines and institutions.  SWEETER unites not-for-profits, community colleges, minority serving institutions, research-intensive universities, and industry from multiple states to develop this research network.  The collaboration leverages expertise in several facets of computational sciences to address long-standing issues encountered in sharing resources by employing a model of resource sharing where each institution is a provider and receiver of resources.

Research specialists from various sites will support domain scientists at site workshops, SWEETER annual events, and online avenues. To encourage these relationships, SWEETER offers a web-portal and shared cyberinfrastructure that will help remove resource barriers faced by community colleges and smaller institutions. SWEETER strengthens efforts for researcher preparation by offering remote and in-person training opportunities, and propagating elements of its learning environment to formal curricular efforts. Importantly, SWEETER employs an innovative evaluation strategy to assess its successes in the aspects of research, training and education. By fostering diverse partnerships developed through existing efforts, SWEETER will significantly broaden the involvement of traditionally underrepresented populations in computing at the K-12, undergraduate and graduate levels of learning. In all, SWEETER offers a flexible, portable and scalable framework to develop communities of practice that will inform the design of future research networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
SWEETER: South West Expertise in Expanding Training, Education and Research is a network of resources, both training and personnel, that collaborated and fostered cooperation across the boundaries of disciplines and institutions. The efficacy of an interdisciplinary research team is frequently limited by a researcher's ability to get cyberinfrastructure expertise in their scientific disciplines. The CyberTeam united not-for-profits, community colleges, instruction-focused universities, research-intensive universities, and industry to develop a regional cyberinfrastructure network. The collaboration offered expertise in several facets of domain computational sciences to scientists at minority serving institutions in Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.  The CyberTeam represented a unique blend of institutions with some supporting intensive research programs, while others were primarily instruction focused.  The skills and levels of cyberinfrastructure adoption among researchers at these schools varied. The SWEETER CyberTeam addressed long-standing issues encountered in enabling information and human resource collaborations across institutions.  Each site benefitted from having an assigned site ambassador who worked with a team of research specialists. These research specialists, also referred to as cyberinfrastructure professionals, assisted domain scientists and contributed to multi-site efforts.  Support could extend from addressing challenges ranging from finding the appropriate computational resource, assisting with coding applications, or designing a computational research workflow. SWEETER strengthened efforts for researcher preparation by offering remote and in-person training opportunities, and propagating elements of its learning environment to formal curricular efforts.  Collaborations between the scientists and the CyberTeam were advanced via local workshops, SWEETER annual events, and online avenues.

These training events fostered innovative and scalable education, training, and development of instructional materials.  Here, SWEETER offers a flexible, portable, and scalable framework to develop communities of practice that inform the design of future research networks and addressed emerging needs and unresolved bottlenecks in CI professional workforce development.  Recognizing the challenges presented by Generative Artificial Intelligence in academia, the SWEETER CyberTeam organized workshops that addressed ways to develop regional CI pools of expertise. the CyberTeam organized regional It employed a model of resource sharing where each institution is a provider and receiver of resources. Simultaneously human resources available at the site were included based on their availability using fractional hires. This approach allowed the project to have immediate impact and improved the integration of CIPs into the research enterprise.


Last Modified: 11/11/2024
Modified by: Dhruva Chakravorty
